questiontext.text: You want to visualize the distribution of GPA values across all 600 students. Which chart type is most appropriate?

feedback.text: Correct! A histogram is ideal for showing the distribution of a single numerical variable, revealing the shape, center, and spread of the data.
Incorrect. Bar charts are for comparing counts or values across categories. For continuous numerical data like GPA, use a histogram.
Incorrect. Scatter plots show the relationship between two numerical variables. For a single variable's distribution, use a histogram.
Incorrect. Line charts show trends over time or a continuous sequence. For distribution of values, use a histogram.

questiontext.text: You want to compare the GPA distributions across five different colleges to see which college has the highest median and which has the most outliers. Which chart type is most appropriate?

feedback.text: Correct! Box plots show the median, quartiles, and outliers for each group, making them ideal for comparing distributions across categories.
Incorrect. Pie charts show proportions of a whole, not distributions. They can't show medians or outliers.
Incorrect. Scatter plots show relationships between two continuous variables, not distributions across categories.
Incorrect. Line charts show trends over a continuous sequence. Box plots are better for comparing distributions across categories.

questiontext.text: You want to explore whether there is a relationship between Credits Attempted and Credits Earned. Which chart type is most appropriate?

feedback.text: Correct! Scatter plots show the relationship between two numerical variables, with each point representing one observation.
Incorrect. Histograms show the distribution of a single variable, not the relationship between two variables.
Incorrect. Bar charts compare values across categories. For two continuous variables, use a scatter plot.
Incorrect. Box plots compare distributions across categories. For the relationship between two continuous variables, use a scatter plot.

questiontext.text: Which code correctly creates a histogram with 20 bins and black edges around each bar?

feedback.text: Correct! The bins parameter controls the number of bars, and edgecolor adds borders to distinguish them.
Incorrect. The correct parameters are bins (not bars) and edgecolor (not border).
Incorrect. The function is plt.hist(), not plt.histogram().
Incorrect. plt.bar() creates bar charts, not histograms. Use plt.hist() for histograms.

questiontext.text: Which set of functions correctly adds a title and axis labels to a matplotlib plot?

feedback.text: Correct! These three functions set the title and axis labels for the current plot.
Incorrect. The functions are xlabel() and ylabel() (no underscore), not x_label() and y_label().
Incorrect. The set_ prefix is used with the axes object (ax.set_title()), not with plt directly.
Incorrect. There are no add_ functions. Use plt.title(), plt.xlabel(), and plt.ylabel().

questiontext.text: Which code correctly saves a matplotlib figure as a PNG file with high resolution?

feedback.text: Correct! plt.savefig() saves the current figure, and dpi (dots per inch) controls resolution. 300 dpi is standard for print quality.
Incorrect. The function is savefig() (not save()), and the parameter is dpi (not resolution).
Incorrect. There is no plt.export() function. Use plt.savefig() to save figures.
Incorrect. Figures don't have a write() method. Use plt.savefig() or fig.savefig().

questiontext.text:
What does this code create?

fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 3)

answer.text: A figure with 6 empty subplots arranged in 2 rows and 3 columns

feedback.text: Correct! plt.subplots(rows, cols) creates a grid of axes. (2, 3) means 2 rows and 3 columns = 6 subplots total.

answer.text: A figure with 6 empty subplots arranged in 3 rows and 2 columns

feedback.text: Incorrect. The first argument is rows, second is columns. (2, 3) means 2 rows, 3 columns.
Incorrect. The arguments define a grid (rows × columns), not a sum. (2, 3) creates 2 × 3 = 6 subplots.

answer.text: An error because subplots requires only one argument

feedback.text: Incorrect. plt.subplots() accepts (nrows, ncols) to create a grid of subplots.

questiontext.text: Which seaborn code creates a box plot showing GPA distribution for each College?

feedback.text: Correct! Seaborn's boxplot takes a DataFrame and column names, automatically creating grouped box plots.
Incorrect. While this may work, the recommended syntax uses data=df with x= and y= parameters for clarity.
Incorrect. The function is sns.boxplot(), not sns.box().
Incorrect. Seaborn uses specific functions like boxplot(), not a generic plot() with kind parameter.

questiontext.text:
What does the hue parameter do in seaborn plots?

sns.scatterplot(data=df, x='Credits_Earned', y='GPA', hue='College')

answer.text: Colors the points differently based on the College column, adding a third variable dimension

feedback.text: Correct! The hue parameter maps a categorical variable to colors, allowing you to visualize a third dimension in the plot.

answer.text: Changes the overall color scheme of the plot to College colors

feedback.text: Incorrect. hue maps data values to colors, not a theme. Each unique College value gets a different color.

answer.text: Filters the data to only show one College at a time

feedback.text: Incorrect. hue shows all data but distinguishes categories by color. It doesn't filter data.

answer.text: Adjusts the brightness of the plot colors

feedback.text: Incorrect. Despite the name "hue," this parameter maps a column to different colors, not brightness.

questiontext.text: In a box plot, what do the individual points plotted beyond the "whiskers" represent?

answer.text: Outliers (values more than 1.5 × IQR from the quartiles)

feedback.text: Correct! Points beyond the whiskers are outliers, typically defined as values more than 1.5 times the interquartile range (IQR) from Q1 or Q3.

answer.text: The minimum and maximum values in the data

feedback.text: Incorrect. The whiskers extend to the min/max within 1.5 × IQR. Points beyond are outliers that exceed this range.

answer.text: The mean values for each category

feedback.text: Incorrect. The line inside the box is the median, not the mean. Points outside whiskers are outliers.

answer.text: Data points that were removed from the analysis

feedback.text: Incorrect. Outliers are displayed, not removed. The box plot shows them so you can identify unusual values.
